item.title: The resolution of disputes and the role of the ECJ in the proposed withdrawal agreement
item.description:

item.title: Revised Brexit Withdrawal Agreement: Analysis 1 Overview
item.description:
Analysis of the revised Brexit withdrawal agreement - October 2019 Professor Steve Peers, University of Essex Introduction While the approval of the Brexit withdrawal agreement is uncertain at present, the UK Parliament’s upcoming vote necessitates an updated analysis of the revised agreement. This updated version includes a revised Protocol on the Irish border and a revised political declaration on the future relationship. This post aims to provide a simplified explanation of the agreement for non-lawyers, outlining its structure and key content...

item.title: An Overview and Initial Observations of the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers from the University of Essex provides a summary and explanation of the Brexit withdrawal agreement, aimed at non-lawyers. The Scope of the Agreement The withdrawal agreement outlines the terms of the UK’s exit from the EU but does not define the long-term relationship between the two entities. The future relationship will be negotiated based on a separate political declaration. Consequences of Non-Ratification If the withdrawal agreement is not ratified, the UK could leave the EU without an agreement, or potentially remain in the EU...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/an-overview-and-initial-observations-of-the-brexit-withdrawal-agreement/

item.title: A Protocol Proposal for Brexit and the Rights of EU27 Citizens
item.description:
Stijn Smismans, Professor of Law, School of Law and Politics, Director of the Centre for European Law and Governance, Cardiff University While a draft Withdrawal Agreement (WA) between the EU and UK, partially agreed upon in March 2018, aims to address the post-Brexit status of EU27 citizens in the UK and British citizens in the EU, concerns remain about the process of securing residency rights. Although the EU has made efforts to safeguard these rights, the focus has been on the scope rather than the process of obtaining them...

item.title: Gazing into the Void: The Future of Citizens' Rights in the Event of a No Deal Brexit
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers, University of Essex* After resisting guarantees for EU27 citizens’ rights in the UK for over two years, the UK government has finally issued a plan outlining the treatment of EU27 citizens in the UK and UK citizens in the EU27 in a “no-deal” Brexit scenario. This comes as the UK Parliament prepares to vote on the withdrawal agreement and after the European Commission published its own position on this matter...

item.title: Returning from Austerity to Legitimacy: An Overview of the European Pillar of Social Rights
item.description:
This piece explores how Juncker can use ‘The European Pillar of Social Rights’ to convey a strong message: that the EU champions dignity, autonomy, and social justice. Claire Kilpatrick (EUI), Elise Muir (Veni Fellow, Maastricht) and Sacha Garben (College of Europe, Bruges) The EU has faced skepticism from its citizens about its commitment to prosperity and better living and working conditions, especially since the financial crisis and the subsequent implementation of austerity measures in various countries...
